the bill (H.R.3625) does two things:

1. It allows the programs to dip into their termination reserves to fund current development, and,

2. It only allows those programs to be cancelled via an act of Congress.

Point 1 sounds to me like it gives certain programs a source of credit, by allowing them to dip into contingency funds.

Point 2 sounds to me like bureaucratic meddling.

As the article points out, if programs like SLS, Orion, and the JWST are so important, why do they have to be protected from cancellation by NASA administration? Why take the decision whether or not to continue funding those programs out of the space agency's hands? We've had plenty of discussions on this forum about the problems with the space shuttle program, and how many of those were the result of bureaucratic meddling. How is ensuring more of the same a good thing?

Not necessarily. While I agree that SLS and Orion are impressive projects, are they worthy of protection for political reasons in a situation where even NASA administration feel they should be canceled? This is sort of the opposite situation to what you are talking about. I like the idea of manned spaceflight, but I don't think we should put all of our (by that I mean the world's space agencies) "eggs" into one basket. Robotic missions like Cassini and Curiosity are spectacular examples of how unmanned missions can do some very important science, and they cost only fraction of the manned missions. What if cost overruns in these "protected" programs force the cancellation of important unmanned missions?

The space shuttle was a failure because it was underfunded and kept undergoing cancellations.

"Underfunded" Yeah, the biggest moneysink spaceship ever was underfunded.

The cancellations and delays it suffered were because the shuttles were simply not able to do that many flights in such short intervals. It was also supposed to be able to put payloads into polar orbits but it never could.

The promises were 1 shuttle flight per week and high re-usability with lower cost per kilogram because of said re-usability. The facts were 1 flight every 2 or 3 months, 2 fatal (but avoidable) failures, and the most expensive spacecraft of its time. And political pressures that caused it to be totally disastrous. Hell, NASA tried to force all payloads to be launched with the shuttle to lessen the costs but even that was useless.

The SLS is going to be another moneysink too.
Probably to protect these program's funding from other certain programs.

The link to bill in the article is borked. This one's correct: https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/113/hr3625/text

It looks like it will be more risky to be NASA contractor for these "protected" projects if the bill is accepted. Also, it may force NASA to drop fundamental science missions, like they did with LISA but not because of budget cuts, just in favor of "protected" missions.

Personally, I think this is good news for mannaed spaceflight supporters. As for probe lovers, not so much.

What concerns me is if the SLS becomes the new space shuttle, having a huge moneysink ferrying parts to lunar and martian bases that are built just so Orion has a destinatuon, instead of exploring yhe solar system....

And should it go overbudget, I fear for the science probes.
They should just give NASA some more cash to work with, not all the bureaucratic non-sense.

It's a terrible news.

Let me explain - having SLS, Orion and JWST protected from cuts means that if anything happens, the rest of the NASA budget will be butchered in order to preserve this holy cows. What is happening now:

Jim Green, the head of NASA's Planetary Science Division, shook things up for planetary scientists this week by announcing a restructuring that will change how the division funds grant proposals. ... That's why some researchers--including Mark Sykes, director of the Planetary Science Institute in Tucson, Arizona--have been railing against the restructuring on Twitter and in the blogosphere. Sykes says the change Green has made is ill-considered because it doesn't take into account the impact on the workforce. "There are many people whose research programs and salaries depend upon successfully proposing to several major programs in 2014," Sykes says. "They have just learned that there will be no opportunity for these programs until 2015. I have had several people tell me that if there is no regular ... call at the regular time in 2014, they will have to look for other employment in a year. There are postdocs whose positions are ending this next year, who would have applied to these programs to get started as independent planetary scientists. They need to find something else to do.

http://news.sciencemag.org/funding/2013/12/nasas-planetary-science-shift-rattles-researchers

is just a prologue to what may happen in the near future with the unmaned exploration program. Besides, what's the point of having heavy lifter if you won't have any payload? And with tightening budget I doubt there will be much money left to build any significant hardware for SLS. That is, before it gets cancelled - let's be honest, politicians don't give a damn about where the rocket goes as long as their voters and companies who sponsor them get contracts.

Oh, and you know what could be a indirect result of this? Cutting spendings is one thing but do you know what's one of the most expensive NASA project now besides SLS/Orion/JWST? ISS. It would be a disaster to see ISS abandoned (no money for prolonging operation to 2020+) only to save Senate Launch System

JWST will be a great tool but it's already a financial monster - what would happen if it get the "too big to fail" status? I'm really worried about this, not that it's my taxpayer money, but because I think this bill wont' be beneficial to science and human exploration of space at all. Quite the contrary, actually. What's even worse, is that nobody knows WHAT FOR is SLS and Orion being built. Asteroid mission? Moon? Mars? Langrange points? There are no money, no hardware and no idea what to do with them. This is exactly the opposite of the Apollo program - huge resources and manpower dedicated to, uhm, you know, building giant rocket because of... reasons. To boldly explore... err... what we're exploring again? Just give us few years and we will come up with something! Don't mind one launch of SLS costing $1.5 bln, who cares that it's more or less the cost of Curiosity mission.

:sigh:

Maybe Chang'e 3 will wake up someone on the Hill.
